Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the influence of informal understandings about biology on formal learning of biological concepts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. This project will integrate research on STEM learning in developmental cognitive science and science education to investigate how cognitive aspects of informal biology facilitate or impede the attainment of formal biological concepts. The study will focus on misconceptions common among biology students that may stem not from the complexity of the concepts themselves, but from deeply held informal ways of understanding the scientific world. It will also test hypotheses about the role of language used by college faculty in reinforcing such ways of knowing, and investigate changes in informal biological thought with the acquisition of formal biological knowledge. The project will target college students and faculty members at multiple levels. The study sample will include 100 entering biology majors and non-majors, 100 graduating biology majors and non-majors, 40 faculty members and a comparable sample of non-science faculty members at Northeastern University and San Francisco State University.

This interdisciplinary project will bring together cognitive scientists and science education researchers to study four specific aims to: (1) examine the use of cognitive construals in formal biological explanations; (2) investigate the nature of instructional language used in university biology; (3) experimentally manipulate the use of cognitive construals in instructional language; and (2) examine changes on traditional cognitive science measures of informal construal based biological reasoning. Data will be collected from study participants at various points of the study through audio recordings of classroom teaching sessions, pre/post surveys, challenge statement assessments, concept inventories, and laboratory experiments. Results emerging from analysis of data from these sources will advance knowledge at the intersection of cognitive psychology and disciplined-based science education research. If findings from this work clarify there is a relationship between informal biological thought and formal biological science learning, it will help establish a new theoretical framework for understanding the acquisition of knowledge in the life sciences. As such, the research will have direct implications for life science teaching at the undergraduate level and fundamentally change the way instructors teach biological concepts that are particularly difficult for students to learn.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What is challenging for citizens to understand about biological ideas that increasingly influence everything in modern life? How do students and instructors integrate their intuitive approaches to biological thought with their formal teaching and learning experiences in the biological sciences. How can insights about the role of intuitive thinking in formal science learning support increased science literacy?

 

Through this NSF CORE award, we have built a pioneering and thriving interdisciplinary collaboration across a biology education research laboratory and a cognitive psychology laboratory to investigate the influence of intuitive reasoning, commonly used to understand and reason about the biological world, in formal biology education contexts. Intuitive reasoning ? referred to as cognitive construals such as anthropic, teleological, and essentialist thinking ? is useful in everyday life; however, these ideas may compete with formal science concepts when students attempt to understand and explain the natural world around them.

 

Through multiple research studies, we have discovered that intuitive ways of knowing ? usually studied only by cognitive psychologists in early childhood ? persist as potential barriers to understanding biology into the college years. Across a variety of biological concepts, we have demonstrated that intuitive reasoning is consistently used by individuals who endorse biology misconceptions, included in their scientifically inaccurate explanations of biological phenomenon, and generally absent in scientifically accurate explanations by experts. Further we have demonstrated that construal-based thinking is not only pervasive among students, but also can also be found in construal-consistent language used by instructors in every university science course studied to date. These findings, replicated across two contrasting universities serving very different student populations, imply that the influence of intuitive reasoning in biology teaching and learning is widespread and under-appreciated.

 

Further, these interdisciplinary collaborations and studies have also resulted in the training of dozens of young scholars, multiple conference presentations, influential publications, and development of novel measurement tools. This award has allowed our laboratories to pioneer collaborations across disciplines that simply did not exist before ? between biologists and psychologists, in particular. The success and productivity of these research collaborations has led to an expansion of such multi-disciplinary collaborations in biology education more broadly, opening new lines of research and fueling new discoveries that scholars in each field alone would be unable to make alone. Finally, our research findings provide new insights to improve biology teaching and learning so that all citizens can connect the basic biology they learn in school to real-world issues.
